text: this is an album which my mum sort of
tried to put together for me of my early
life and pictured me with my dad looking
back at the past my overriding sense was
how little I really knew my father all
the scale of the problems he was facing
he looks quite distant quite you know
it's a dark mood he looks like and then
that was that was typical of later on in
his life what I do know is that in the
very early hours of one January morning
in 1989 my father left the family home
and took his own life I'm not angry at
him for doing it it feels very sorry for
the poor guy and I'm just confused as to
why that happened
the latest national statistics show the
shockingly high incidence of male
suicide nearly 5000 men take their lives
each year and it remains the biggest
killer of men under 50 when somebody
chooses to take their own life there are
as many reasons as there are individuals
who've chosen to do that and I think
it's it's very it's very difficult but
it's important that we accept that you
know we will probably never know the
individual reasons behind individual
cases
professor Rory O'Connor conducts a wide
range of experiments into the psychology
of suicidal behavior living life over
what we're trying to do with this task
is trying to tap into that to understand
and predict who's more likely to kill
themselves and crucially also try and
understand better the distinction
between people who have thoughts of
suicide and go no further how do they
differ from individuals who should make
the next step translate the thoughts
into action my own father in his 40s was
in the most vulnerable age group as
incidents of suicide peak among men in
that decade to this day I'm still unsure
what he did what he did
